docs.lead_paragraph: Emily Davison, a 12-year-old seventh grader at the Trinity School in Manhattan, used to think she was overweight. Recently, she changed her mind. Emily didn't lose a single pound to change her attitude. She went online and consulted iEmily, a new site devoted to helping teenage girls -- and not just ones named Emily -- get answers to questions about physical and mental health. After reading articles on the site about healthy weight and body image, Emily realized she wasn't fat after all.

headline.main: Teenagers Find Health Answers With a Click

docs.abstract: Teenagers use Internet to visit Web sites devoted to health issues; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q: Would requiring medical students to identify themselves as such to patients pose problems for hospitals? Often, hospital patients are unaware that they are being treated by medical students or residents rather than fully trained physicians. Gale Scott asked two experts to examine the issue, and the following are edited excerpts from her interviews with them. THIS creates a problem for teaching hospitals. Of course patients should know who is caring for them. The issue is that some patients then feel free to refuse care by a student or a resident.
docs.abstract: Drs Peter Schwartz and Richard F Corlin argue the question of whether requiring medical students to identify themselves as such to patients would pose problems for teaching hospitals; Schwartz says it would, and Corlin that it would not; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Q: Would requiring medical students to identify themselves as such to patients pose problems for hospitals?       Often, hospital patients are unaware that they are being treated by medical students or residents rather than fully trained physicians....

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. William Prusoff has the same half-proud, half-mortified air these days that any ordinary, unassuming parent might sport when an offspring becomes wildly successful at a chosen career, raking in billions of dollars despite notoriously cutthroat business tactics. The fact that Dr. Prusoff's successful offspring happens to be a molecule -- the AIDS drug stavudine, or d4T -- changes things not at all. Especially since, to his consternation, his brainchild has now dragged him with it into the media spotlight as world attention focuses on the pricing and availability of AIDS drugs.

headline.main: A Molecular Offspring, Off to Join the AIDS Wars

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr William Prusoff, who derives considerable income from sale of AIDS drug he discovered--stavudine, or d4T--but supports its lower cost and wider distribution in poor countries; Bristol-Myers Squibb, distributor, recently announced sharp reduction of drug's price in Africa and removed barriers to sale of generic equivalents there; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. William Prusoff has the same half-proud, half-mortified air these days that any ordinary, unassuming parent might sport when an offspring becomes wildly successful at a chosen career, raking in billions of dollars despite notoriously cutthroat...

docs.lead_paragraph: Back in the 1980's, when my husband and I found out that our two sons had asthma, we assumed our slobbish ways were to blame. Dust balls and cat dander were the big crimes then, and we were guilty on both counts. Microscopic insects called dust mites, and their droppings, even more microscopic (one would hope), were said to cause asthma. So were bits of skin flaking off pets. We must have been wading through invisible, knee-high piles of mite manure and molecules of cat.
docs.abstract: Denise Grady article recalls how she and her husband, whose two sons have asthma, would fanatically clean their house to try to rid it of harmful dust and cat dander, only to read recently of study that claims asthma comes on, and is on the rise in America and other rich countries, because overly protective parents keep their houses too clean, depriving children of exposure to germs, dirt, toxins and irritants they need to prepare their little immune systems to take on the world; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Years ago, the only place you were likely to find green tea was in an Asian restaurant. Now nearly every supermarket sells it, both regular and decaffeinated. In the last decade green tea has acquired a reputation as a preventive of many scourges, including heart disease and cancer. But is it? How good is the evidence? And is there a downside to drinking lots of it? The evidence is conflicting, but to date it does not indicate green tea is a panacea or the elixir many believe it to be. For example, Japanese researchers reported March 1 in The New England Journal of Medicine that among 26,311 residents of northern Japan followed for eight years, the consumption of green tea showed no effect on the risk of developing stomach cancer, a leading killer among cancers in Japan.

headline.main: Finding Tea's Place on a Healthful Table

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on green tea, and conflicting evidence regarding its health benefits; reports that to date, evidence does not indicate that green tea is a panacea or elixir many believe it to be; photo (M)
